head.title: Group Will Persist With Coke Boycott

hedline.hl1: Group Will Persist With Coke Boycott

abstract.p: Committee for Corporate Justice, led by former Coca-Cola Co benefits manager Larry Jones, says group will press on with boycott against company despite lack of support from major civil rights organizations; group is demanding that company change what group contends is discriminatory treatment of black employees (S)

block.p: A group led by a former Coca-Cola benefits manager said today that it would press on with a boycott against the company despite a lack of support from major civil rights organizations.

The former benefits manager, Larry Jones, said that his group, the Committee for Corporate Justice, which includes some former and current Coca-Cola employees, will ask Atlanta businesses and churches to remove Coke vending machines and will distribute literature at local transit stations.
A group led by a former Coca-Cola benefits manager said today that it would press on with a boycott against the company despite a lack of support from major civil rights organizations.

The former benefits manager, Larry Jones, said that his group, the Committee for Corporate Justice, which includes some former and current Coca-Cola employees, will ask Atlanta businesses and churches to remove Coke vending machines and will distribute literature at local transit stations.
The group is demanding that the company change what the group contends is discriminatory treatment of black employees.

Mr. Jones, who is not among the plaintiffs in the suit, announced the boycott at the company's annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., on April 19; Coca-Cola says the action has not had a discernible impact.
